Fiction

THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95; special illustrated edition, $35.) A murder at the Louvre leads to clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.

THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
STATE OF FEAR, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $27.95.) Reverse eco-terrorists create natural disasters to convince the public that global warming is real.
A SALTY PIECE OF LAND, by Jimmy Buffett. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) A cowboy's life is changed forever when he meets a 101-year-old woman who hires him to be a lighthouse keeper in the Bahamas.
LONDON BRIDGES, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The F.B.I. agent Alex Cross contends with two deadly enemies: the supercriminal known as the Wolf and the assassin known as the Weasel.
BLACK WIND, by Clive Cussler and Dirk Cussler. (Putnam, $27.95.) Dirk Pitt and his children confront a villain who has acquired biotoxins from World War II.

NIGHT FALL, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $26.95.) A husband and wife who work for an antiterrorism task force reopen the investigation into the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 over the Atlantic, off Long Island, in 1996.
LIFE EXPECTANCY, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) A pastry chef must struggle all his life against a family of evil madmen.
WHITEOUT, by Ken Follett. (Dutton, $26.95.) In the middle of a Christmas Eve blizzard in Scotland, a canister filled with a deadly virus goes missing.
I AM CHARLOTTE SIMMONS, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.95.) A very smart, very innocent freshman from the Blue Ridge Mountains is amazed by what she finds at a prestigious university.

THE PLOT AGAINST AMERICA, by Philip Roth. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) The experiences of a Jewish family in Newark after Charles A. Lindbergh defeats Franklin D. Roosevelt in the 1940 presidential election.
ECHOES, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $27.) During World War II, a Jewish woman and her daughter, a Carmelite nun, are trapped in Hitler's Europe.
A REDBIRD CHRISTMAS, by Fannie Flagg. (Random House, $17.95.) After receiving a grim diagnosis from his doctor, a Chicago resident moves to a small town.
THE CHRISTMAS THIEF, by Mary Higgins Clark and Carol Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster/Scribner, $21.) Hidden treasure lies within the branches of a giant blue spruce destined for Rockefeller Center.
THE GODFATHER RETURNS, by Mark Winegardner. (Random House, $26.95.) Continuing the story begun in Mario Puzo's novel ''The Godfather.''

List
Nonfiction
AMERICA (The BOOK), by Jon Stewart, Ben Karlin, David Javerbaum et al. (Warner, $24.95.) ''The Daily Show'' offers a lavishly illustrated parody of a civics textbook.
CHRONICLES: Volume One, by Bob Dylan. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) Recollections and observations from the singer-songwriter.
FAITHFUL, by Stewart O'Nan and Stephen King. (Scribner, $26.) Two novelists -- and die-hard Boston Red Sox fans -- chronicle the 2004 championship season, from spring training to the World Series.
WHEN WILL JESUS BRING THE PORK CHOPS? by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $23.95.) Another volume of observations and opinions from the stand-up comedian.
HIS EXCELLENCY, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf, $26.95.) A biography of George Washington, by the author of ''Founding Brothers.''
EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss. (Gotham, $17.50.) An Englishwoman expounds on the use and misuse of punctuation marks.
MY LIFE, by Bill Clinton. (Knopf, $35.) From Hope, Ark., to the White House: the autobiography of the 42nd president.
FAVRE, by Brett Favre and Bonita Favre with Chris Havel. (N.F.L. Publishing/RuggedLand, $29.95.) A profusely illustrated book about the Green Bay Packers' quarterback.
HOW TO TALK TO A LIBERAL (IF YOU MUST), by Ann Coulter. (Crown Forum, $26.95.) A collection of the columnist's writings about what's wrong with liberals.
THE GAMES DO COUNT, by Brian Kilmeade. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $24.95.) Celebrities and politicians discuss how sports have changed their lives. (+)
SHARING GOOD TIMES, by Jimmy Carter. (Simon & Schuster, $21.) The 39th president recalls experiences both challenging and enjoyable.
*WILL IN THE WORLD, by Stephen Greenblatt. (Norton, $26.95.) A Harvard humanities professor sets out to explain how Shakespeare became the greatest of all playwrights.
THE LAST SEASON, by Phil Jackson with Michael Arkush. (Penguin Press, $24.95.) The former coach of the Los Angeles Lakers recalls his final year with Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant.
DRESS YOUR FAMILY IN CORDUROY AND DENIM, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The humorist's latest collection of essays.
SPORTS ILLUSTRATED: THE ANNIVERSARY BOOK. (Sports Illustrated/Time Inc., $29.95.) Fifty years of writing and pictures from the magazine.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Dec. 25, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest
THE WORLD OF CHRISTOPHER MARLOWE, by David Riggs. (John Macrae/Holt, $30.) How a street fighter and spy who was the son of a cobbler became one of England's greatest poets.
DE KOONING: An American Master, by Mark Stevens and Annalyn Swan. (Knopf, $35.) An exploration at length of de Kooning's life and work.
A TALE OF LOVE AND DARKNESS, by Amos Oz. (Harcourt, $26.) A memoir by the Israeli novelist, mourning the deaths of his mother long ago and of the socialist Zion in his own time.
AMERICAN BRUTUS: John Wilkes Booth and the Lincoln Conspiracies, by Michael W. Kauffman. (Random House, $29.95.) Booth meant to take out the government, and nearly did.
THE COMPLETE CARTOONS OF THE NEW YORKER. (Black Dog/Leventhal, $60.) Some 68,000 cartoons that have shaped national sensibilities since the 1920's; a huge book and two CD's.
THE SELECTED LETTERS OF TENNESSEE WILLIAMS: Volume II, 1945-1957. (New Directions, $39.95.) The travails of an unshakable romantic who made art from life's hardest parts.
THE DICTATORS: Hitler's Germany and Stalin's Russia, by Richard Overy. (Norton, $35.) A historian seeks the essence of totalitarianism.
ARMAGEDDON: The Battle for Germany, 1944-1945, by Max Hastings. (Knopf, $30.) Though obviously beaten, the Germans wouldn't give up; an experienced journalist pursues the paradox.

THE MAN IN THE FLYING LAWN CHAIR: And Other Excursions and Observations, by George Plimpton. (Random House, $24.95.) A posthumous collection gathers Plimpton's generous articles about eccentrics, dreamers and the rest of us.
RAMMER JAMMER YELLOW HAMMER: A Journey Into the Heart of Fan Mania, by Warren St. John. (Crown, $24.) On the road with the University of Alabama's football faithful.
DREAM SEASON: A Professor Joins America's Oldest Semi-Pro Football Team, by Bob Cowser Jr. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) The author relives his not-so-glorious high school days on the gridiron.
The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books
